description: From Ancient Greek ϕλογιστός (phlogistós, “flammable”), from φλόξ (phlóx, “flame”); in chemistry sense reinforced by phlogist(on) +‎ -ic.

adjectives.description: phlogistic (comparative more phlogistic, superlative most phlogistic)

entries.meaning: (medicine) Inflammatory; pertaining to inflammations and fevers. [from 18th c.]
(chemistry, physics, now historical) Pertaining to or containing phlogiston. [from 18th c.]
examples: His experiments, with their phlogistic explanations, led him to believe that the only distinct species of air were the fixed, alkaline, and acid.
